required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Determinants of the Effectiveness of Robot-assisted Hand Movement Training
clinical_study.official_title: Determinants of the Effectiveness of Robot-assisted Hand Movement Training

brief_summary.textblock: We would like to investigate the effectiveness of somatosensory input in robot-assisted hand motor rehabilitation after stroke.

detailed_description.textblock: From previous studies, we learnt that stroke survivor with impaired finger proprioception did not achieve a functional benefit from robotic finger training. For this study, we would like to determine if and the extent of finger proprioception can be improved through targeted robotic proprioceptive training and the response to subsequent robotic finger movement training. We would also include imagining studies via MRI/fMRI/EEG to provide more insights to determine who responds best to proprioceptive training.

primary_outcome.description: We compare the change of Box and Block Test scores from baseline evaluation to 1-month post intervention. Participants are instructed to move as many blocks as possible, one at a time, from one compartment in a box to a second compartment over a divider for a period of 60 seconds; each block that is moved is counted, and multiple blocks moved at the same time are counted as a single block. The higher scores indicate a better outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Fugl-Meyer Motor Assessment of the Upper Extremity
secondary_outcome.description: We will measure the change of the Fugl-Meyer Motor Assessment scores from the baseline evaluation to 1-month post intervention. Fugl-Meyer is a 66-point scale measuring the movement pattern of upper extremities. The higher scores indicate a better outcome.

We will measure the change of the Motor Activity Log (MAL) mean scores from the baseline evaluation to 1-month post intervention. The Motor Activity Log is a 30 questionnaire that collect subjective measure of an individual's real life functional upper limb performance. The higher scores indicate a better outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in finger proprioception measured using the Crisscross Assessment.
secondary_outcome.description: We will measure the change in finger proprioception scores from the baseline evaluation to 1-month post intervention. Finger proprioception is measured by using the FINGER Crisscross Assessment which we slowly move the index and middle fingers with the FINGER robot past each other without any visual input. We then ask study participants to press a key when they feel the fingers are overlapped. Finger proprioception is measured by the error which will be quantified as the mean magnitude of finger separation error at the metacarpal joint when the key is pressed. The lower scores indicate a better outcome.

arm_group.description: Participants with intact finger proprioception will undergo new FINGER robotic training with no physical assistance 3 times a week for a period of 3 weeks.
Participants with intact finger proprioception will undergo new FINGER robotic training with physical assistance 3 times a week for a period of 3 weeks.

Participants with poor finger proprioception will undergo intensive, robotic-assisted proprioceptive training for a 3-week period prior to new FINGER robotic training with physical assistance 3 times a week for a period of 3 weeks.
Participants with poor finger proprioception will undergo new FINGER robotic training with physical assistance 3 times a week for a period of 3 weeks.

intervention.description: NEW FINGER exoskeleton is a robotic device that can provide assistance and resistance to thumb and finger movement
Proprioception Extension Trainer device is a robotic device that can provide target specific finger proprioception training.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Age 18 to 85 years
2. Suffered from a single ischemic stroke (radiologically confirmed) at least 6-months prior to enrollment
3. An ability to score at least 3 blocks on the Box and Block Test
Exclusion Criteria:
1. A substantial decrease in alertness, language reception or attention
2. Pregnant or lactating
3. Advanced liver, kidney, cardiac or pulmonary disease
4. Plan to alter any current participation in other rehabilitation therapy in the time period of the study
5. A terminal medical diagnosis consistent with survival < 1 year
6. Coexistent major neurological disease
7. Coexistent major psychiatric disease
8. A history of significant alcohol or drug abuse in the prior 3 years
9. Current enrollment in another study related to stroke or stroke recovery
10. Any other medical contraindication to participation in this study evaluated by our team physician.

reference.citation: Rowe JB, Chan V, Ingemanson ML, Cramer SC, Wolbrecht ET, Reinkensmeyer DJ. Robotic Assistance for Training Finger Movement Using a Hebbian Model: A Randomized Controlled Trial. Neurorehabil Neural Repair. 2017 Aug;31(8):769-780. doi: 10.1177/1545968317721975.

Ingemanson ML, Rowe JB, Chan V, Wolbrecht ET, Cramer SC, Reinkensmeyer DJ. Use of a robotic device to measure age-related decline in finger proprioception. Exp Brain Res. 2016 Jan;234(1):83-93. doi: 10.1007/s00221-015-4440-4. Epub 2015 Sep 16.
